verses.text: I will sing of the Lord's steadfast love forever; with my mouth I will make known your faithfulness to all generations.
verses.comment: The Hebrew word for 'steadfast love' is 'hesed', which points to God's covenantal mercy. Christians see this as anticipating the New Covenant in Christ.

verses.text: For I said, 'Steadfast love will be built up forever; in the heavens you will establish your faithfulness.'
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness is portrayed as enduring, fulfilled in Christ, the Son enthroned in heaven. See Hebrews 6:19–20 about Jesus as our anchor in heaven.

verses.text: You said, 'I have made a covenant with my chosen one; I have sworn to David my servant:'
verses.comment: This is a reference to the Davidic Covenant, solemnized in 2 Samuel 7. This covenant finds its ultimate fulfillment in Jesus, David’s descendant (Luke 1:32–33).

verses.text: 'I will establish your offspring forever, and build up your throne for all generations.' Selah
verses.comment: The perpetual throne is seen by Christians as a prophecy of Christ’s eternal kingship. Catholic tradition sees the Church as the visible continuation of this reign.

verses.text: Let the heavens praise your wonders, O Lord, your faithfulness in the assembly of the holy ones!
verses.comment: The assembly of the holy ones may subtly foreshadow the communion of saints—a key Catholic doctrine connecting heaven and earth.

verses.text: For who in the skies can be compared to the Lord? Who among the sons of God is like the Lord?
verses.comment: 'Sons of God' likely refers to angelic beings, showing God's supremacy over all celestial creatures.

verses.text: A God greatly to be feared in the council of the holy ones, and awesome above all who are around him?
verses.comment: The heavenly council motif can be linked to the worship of God in the heavenly liturgy (see Revelation 4).

verses.text: O Lord God of hosts, who is mighty as you are, O Lord, with your faithfulness all around you?
verses.comment: 'God of hosts' stresses God's command over angelic armies—a heavenly dimension celebrated in the Mass.

verses.text: You rule the raging of the sea; when its waves rise, you still them.
verses.comment: Jesus calming the sea echoes this verse, attesting to His divinity (see Mark 4:39), fulfilling what is attributed here to the Lord alone.

verses.text: You crushed Rahab like a corpse; you scattered your enemies with your mighty arm.
verses.comment: 'Rahab' here symbolizes Egypt. God’s victory is re-presented in every age—Catholic liturgy interprets these mighty acts as types pointing to Christ’s Paschal victory.

verses.text: The heavens are yours; the earth also is yours; the world and all that is in it, you have founded them.
verses.comment: All creation belongs to God—a truth reflected in the Church’s teaching on the goodness of creation (cf. Genesis 1, CCC 299).

verses.text: North and south, you have created them; Tabor and Hermon joyously praise your name.
verses.comment: Mount Tabor, later, is the place of the Transfiguration of Jesus (cf. Matthew 17:1-8), revealing Christ's glory.

verses.text: You have a mighty arm; strong is your hand, high your right hand.
verses.comment: God’s right hand symbolizes strength and salvation (see Acts 2:33, Christ exalted to God’s right hand).

verses.text: Righteousness and justice are the foundation of your throne; steadfast love and faithfulness go before you.
verses.comment: These are the defining attributes of God’s reign—which Catholics see embodied in Christ’s Kingdom present in the Church (Luke 17:21).

verses.text: Blessed are the people who know the festal shout, who walk, O Lord, in the light of your face,
verses.comment: 'Festal shout' hints at liturgical celebration—a central aspect of Catholic worship as an ongoing heavenly reality (see Hebrews 12:22-24).

verses.text: who exult in your name all the day and in your righteousness are exalted.
verses.comment: True righteousness comes from union with God—a doctrine developed in New Testament justification (see Romans 3:22).

verses.text: For you are the glory of their strength; by your favor our horn is exalted.
verses.comment: 'Horn' symbolizes strength and kingship, ultimately fulfilled in Christ (Luke 1:69: 'He has raised up a horn of salvation…').

verses.text: For our shield belongs to the Lord, our king to the Holy One of Israel.
verses.comment: The kings of Israel are anointed to prefigure Christ, the true Messiah (cf. Hebrews 1:8).

verses.text: Of old you spoke in a vision to your godly one, and said: 'I have granted help to one who is mighty; I have exalted one chosen from the people.'
verses.comment: ‘Godly one’ (Hebrew: chasid) may refer to Samuel or David, but more perfectly, prefigures Christ God’s Chosen One (Luke 23:35).

verses.text: I have found David my servant; with my holy oil I have anointed him,
verses.comment: David’s anointing with holy oil prefigures Christ (Greek ‘Christos’ = Anointed One), and sacramental anointing in Christian practice (see 2 Cor. 1:21).

verses.text: so that my hand shall be established with him; my arm also shall strengthen him.
verses.comment: Christ is upheld by the Father in His mission; Christians are upheld by grace.

verses.text: The enemy shall not outwit him; the wicked shall not humble him.
verses.comment: Final security is assured in God’s anointed—applied spiritually to Jesus who defeats all spiritual enemies.

verses.text: I will crush his foes before him and strike down those who hate him.
verses.comment: Fulfilled in Christ (cf. 1 Cor. 15:25), who reigns until all enemies are put under His feet.

verses.text: My faithfulness and my steadfast love shall be with him, and in my name his horn shall be exalted.
verses.comment: ‘Horn’ again points to Christ’s victory and exulted status as Messiah and High Priest.

verses.text: I will set his hand on the sea and his right hand on the rivers.
verses.comment: Universal dominion promised to David’s heir points forward to the cosmic reign of Christ (see Matthew 28:18).

verses.text: He shall cry to me, 'You are my Father, my God, and the Rock of my salvation.'
verses.comment: Jesus openly refers to God as Father—unique intimacy that Christians share by adoption (see Gal. 4:6).

verses.text: And I will make him the firstborn, the highest of the kings of the earth.
verses.comment: ‘Firstborn’ is a royal title; see how Paul applies this explicitly to Jesus (Colossians 1:15) as the Head of creation and the Church.

verses.text: My steadfast love I will keep for him forever, and my covenant will stand firm for him.
verses.comment: God’s everlasting covenant is finally revealed in Christ and the New Covenant (see Hebrews 13:20).

verses.text: I will establish his offspring forever and his throne as the days of the heavens.
verses.comment: This messianic promise is fulfilled in Jesus’ eternal kingship—the Catholic understanding sees the Church as sharing in this ongoing reign.

verses.text: If his children forsake my law and do not walk according to my rules,
verses.comment: God’s covenant is conditional for the heirs—showing need for perseverance and faithfulness, key themes in Catholic life (see Philippians 2:12).

verses.text: if they violate my statutes and do not keep my commandments,
verses.comment: Obedience is expected in response to God’s love, foreshadowing the moral life of the Christian (see John 14:15).

verses.text: then I will punish their transgression with the rod and their iniquity with stripes,
verses.comment: God disciplines His people for their good; similar to how the Church teaches correction leads to holiness (cf. Hebrews 12:6).

verses.text: but I will not remove from him my steadfast love or be false to my faithfulness.
verses.comment: God’s mercy endures—especially in the Incarnation, Sacraments, and ongoing forgiveness within the Church.

verses.text: I will not violate my covenant or alter the word that went forth from my lips.
verses.comment: God’s promises are irrevocable, a foundation of Christian assurance.

verses.text: Once for all I have sworn by my holiness; I will not lie to David.
verses.comment: A solemn oath guaranteed by God Himself—Christ's priesthood is described in similar terms ('once for all', Hebrews 7:27).

verses.text: His offspring shall endure forever, his throne as long as the sun before me.
verses.comment: God promises a never-ending line culminating in the everlasting reign of Christ.

verses.text: Like the moon it shall be established forever, a faithful witness in the skies.” Selah
verses.comment: The moon is a visible sign—a theme echoed in sacramental theology, where visible signs communicate God's covenant faithfulness.

verses.text: But now you have cast off and rejected; you are full of wrath against your anointed.
verses.comment: This is the lament over apparent rejection—a tension resolved in Christ who bears God’s wrath, yet is vindicated in resurrection.

verses.text: You have renounced the covenant with your servant; you have defiled his crown in the dust.
verses.comment: Earthly Israel's throne falls, but the messianic hope persists—a hope realized spiritually in the Messiah.

verses.text: You have breached all his walls; you have laid his strongholds in ruins.
verses.comment: The destruction is part of God’s discipline, understood in Christian thought as a call to repentance and renewal.

verses.text: All who pass by plunder him; he has become the scorn of his neighbors.
verses.comment: The humiliation of the king points forward to Christ’s suffering and rejection (see Luke 23:35).

verses.text: You have exalted the right hand of his foes; you have made all his enemies rejoice.
verses.comment: God allows enemies to triumph for a time—a mysterious aspect of divine providence.

verses.text: You have also turned back the edge of his sword, and you have not made him stand in battle.
verses.comment: God’s presence is essential for victory—echoes the Church’s teaching on the necessity of grace.

verses.text: You have made his splendor to cease and cast his throne to the ground.
verses.comment: Loss of earthly splendor contrasts with Christ’s spiritual exaltation 'on the wood of the Cross' (see Philippians 2:8-9).

verses.text: You have cut short the days of his youth; you have covered him with shame. Selah
verses.comment: Imagery of the humiliated king is seen fulfilled in Christ, the suffering servant.

verses.text: How long, O Lord? Will you hide yourself forever? How long will your wrath burn like fire?
verses.comment: A heartfelt lament that turns into hope. Catholic spirituality sees value in such honest prayer (see Lamentations 3:21-24).

verses.text: Remember how short my time is! For what vanity you have created all the children of man!
verses.comment: A reflection on mortality, preparing the way for the Christian hope in resurrection.

verses.text: What man can live and never see death? Who can deliver his soul from the power of Sheol? Selah
verses.comment: A rhetorical question answered only by Christ, who conquers death (cf. John 11:25, 'I am the resurrection and the life').

verses.text: Lord, where is your steadfast love of old, which by your faithfulness you swore to David?
verses.comment: A recalled longing for God’s faithfulness, fulfilled mystically in Christ and sacramentally in the Eucharist.

verses.text: Remember, O Lord, how your servants are mocked, and how I bear in my heart the insults of all the many nations,
verses.comment: Suffering for God’s sake is seen as redemptive and participation in Christ’s passion—a central tenet of Christian life.

verses.text: with which your enemies mock, O Lord, with which they mock the footsteps of your anointed.
verses.comment: Prophetic of the mocking of Christ on His way to Calvary—fulfilled in the events of the Passion.

verses.text: Blessed be the Lord forever! Amen and Amen.
verses.comment: A doxology closes the psalm. Early Christian liturgy (like the Catholic Mass) still ends with 'Amen,' showing continuity with the worship of Israel.
